column2: >Are you curious why scalable applications are so popular? You’ve probably heard the word scalability but are not really familiar with it. That’s why in this post we explain what application scalability is and why it matters in order to guarantee the successful growth of your business.
>What Is Application Scalability?

>Scalability is the ability of an application to handle a growing number of customers, clients, or users. It is directly related to the ability of your current or future developer to maintain the app and its data consistency.

>Application scalability guarantees that, in time, your app will be capable of efficiently sustaining a high growth of its user base. To do this, an app needs to be correctly configured. This means the right software protocols and hardware are aligned to meet a high number of requests per minute (RPM).

>Each user interaction when using your app generates a request, and making sure that each request is attended is a must. To do this, you can always increase your computer processing capacity, or even better, hire a flexible web service provider. This allows you to hire only the capacity you need without the risk of running short of request processing capacity, leaving your app’s performance unaffected, and your users happy.

column2: >How to Determine If Your App Is Scalable

>Ask yourself this question: is your app’s code structure and associated hardware, as it stands today, able to scale up to exponential growth? If you have any doubts, you need to seriously consider your app’s scalability issue.

>Your app needs to be scalable from the start, way before it’s launched to the public. And the only way to truly know if the app can handle rapid scaling is by extensive testing. The reason scalability testing
column3: > is necessary is that you need to know if your app can handle the enormous workload ahead while avoiding costly glitches and constant updates.

>Applications work the same way. Even if your customers want all the benefits of using your app, they’ll be turned away by simple scalability and performance issues.
